member.name: T:x2.Getopt
member.summary: Getopt is a clone of the GNU C getopt.

member.name: F:x2.Getopt.NoArgument
member.summary: Indicates that the option does not take an argument.

member.name: F:x2.Getopt.RequiredArgument
member.summary: Indicates that the option requires an argument.

member.name: F:x2.Getopt.OptionalArgument
member.summary: Indicates that the option takes an optional argument.

member.name: P:x2.Getopt.Opt
member.summary: Returns the last option character.

member.name: P:x2.Getopt.OptArg
member.summary: Gets the value of the option argument, for those options that accept an argument.

member.name: P:x2.Getopt.OptInd
member.summary: Gets the index of the next element to be processed in args.

remarks.para: The initial value is 0. Unlike C getopt, optind is a read-only property of Getopt, and you should use Reset() method in order to prepare Getopt for a new scanning, instead of resetting optind directly.
Once Getopt has processed all the options, you can use optind to determine where the remaining non-options begin in args.

member.name: P:x2.Getopt.OptOpt
member.summary: Gets the option character, when Getopt encounters an unknown option character or an option without a required argument.

member.name: P:x2.Getopt.OptErr
member.summary: Gets or sets whether Getopt would print out error messages or not.

remarks.para: If opterr is true (default), then Getopt prints an error message to the standard error stream if it encounters an unknown option or an option without a required argument.
If you set opterr to false, Getopt does not print any messages, but it still returns the character '?' to indicate an error.

member.name: P:x2.Getopt.LongIndex
member.summary: Gets the index of the log option relative to longopts.
member.remarks: A negative integer means that there is no long option matched.

member.name: P:x2.Getopt.LongOnly
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this Getopt would run in long_only mode.

remarks.para: If long_only is true, '-' as well as '--' can indicate a long option. If an option that starts with '-' (not '--') matches a short option, not a long option, then it is parsed as a short option.

member.name: M:x2.Getopt.Next
member.summary: Returns the next option character.
member.remarks: When no more option is available, it returns -1. There may still be more non-options remaining.

members.member:
Compares this Slot with the specified Slot object.
Implements IComparable(T).CompareTo interface.
A Slot object to be compared with this.
A value that indicates the relative order of the Slot objects being compared. Zero return value means that this is equal to other, while negative(positive) integer return value means that this is less(greater) than other.

members.member:
Determines whether the specified Cell object is equivalent to this one.
A Cell is said to be equivalent to the other if its fingerprint is equivalent to the other's, and all the fingerprinted properties of the other exactly matches with their counterparts.
Given two Cell objects x and y, x.Equivalent(y) returns true if:
x.fingerprint.Equivalent(y.fingerprint) returns true.
All the fingerprinted properties in x are equal to those in y.

member.summary: Determines whether the specified Cell object is equivalent to this one based on the given fingerprint.

member.name: T:x2.EventSink
member.summary: Cleanup helper base class for any event-consuming classes.
member.remarks:
x2 event handlers are built on C# delegates. In case of an instance method delegate, it keeps a strong reference to the method target object. This means that when you bind an event with an instance method, the target object will never be garbage-collected as long as the handler delegate lives, resulting in undesirable memory leak.
EventSink is here to handle the case. First, let your event-consuming class be derived from EventSink. When the object is no longer needed, explicitly call its Dispose() method to ensure that all the event bindings to the object are removed so that the object is properly garbage-collected.
An EventSink object should be initialized with a single specific flow. And an object instance of any EventSink-derived class should never be shared by two or more different flows. These are constraints by design.

member.name: P:x2.EventSink.Flow

member.summary: Returns the hash code for the current object.

members.member:
Determines whether the specified Fingerprint object is equivalent to this one.
A Fingerprint is said to be equivalent to the other when it covers all the bits set in the other.
Given two Fingerprint objects x and y, x.Equivalent(y) returns true if:
y.Length is greater than or equal to x.Length
All the bits set in x are also set in y
